threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
/lit/ is for the discussion of literature, specifically books (fiction & non-fiction), short stories, poetry, creative writing, etc. If you want to discuss history, religion, or the humanities, go to /his/. If you want to discuss politics, go to /pol/. Philosophical discussion can go on either /lit/ or /his/, but those discussions of philosophy that take place on /lit/ should be based around specific philosophical works to which posters can refer.

Check the wiki, the catalog, and the archive before asking for advice or recommendations, and please refrain from starting new threads for questions that can be answered by a search engine.

/lit/ is a slow board! Please take the time to read what others have written, and try to make thoughtful, well-written posts of your own. Bump replies are not necessary.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21268738
>What do you mean my "more than one poetry"?
there being more than one qualitatively different category which we lump together and call it "poetry"

>Poetry should generally be read like one would normally read prose, and be recited as such
well, there are theater plays which were written without the author intending them to be performed... I was wondering if in poetry there is something similar, or is poetry closer to song (than to prose, for example)

>There should be no difference between poetry that is and that is not your own, except in that it is more personal to you.
yeah, this is a nice perspective, but if we reduce poetry to "finely crafted speech" we ultimately don't need a separate category for it, would we?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21268803
Well of course there are different kinds of poetry. Ballads can be sung or read. Epics were recited to audiences. People read slam poetry all the time now, but I think it's complete trash. Poetry is closer to song than prose, but it isn't sung like songs are. The music of poetry is in the arrangment of the words and punctuation, not from a singer. There is overlap in all categories of literary writing, but the categories still exist and are useful. If you want something to be sung, check out ballads and other sung poetic forms. I'm forgetting one or two more.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21265453
>>21266951
>>21267093
It's actually a poem by Paul Verlaine. Translated sounds like this:

The long sobs
Of violins
Of autumn
Wound my heart
With a monotonous
Languor.

All breathless
And pale, when
The hour sounds,
I remember
The old days
And I cry;

And I go
In the ill wind
That carries me
Here, there,
Like the
Dead leaf.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21269241
Thank you for your considerate reply. It made me realize that maybe my question involves content (lyricism) more than form... or even the multiple ways these two may be combined. We usually read poetry in its finished form (I think slam poetry is trash too), so we have a hard time sympathizing with the author or the audience. What I wanted to know is -- does any research exist on this subject? Namely to aid in closing the gap between the reactions of the intended audience and the reception of somebody reading the same work in a book. Of course the imagination of the reader is also a valuable resource, hence why my initial differentiation between "composing for recital" and "publishing directly"...

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
I started meditating because of insomnia and i wanted to be free of obsessive thoughts. I downloaded WakingUp app, i did it every day until free period ended. Then i turned into non-guided meditation, but because i never read books about it, my method was similiar to WakingUp one and inspired by anon posts too - i breathe in and out with closed eyes, sometimes i count breaths but then i try to stop counting, and turn to "passive observer" of breaths - keeping concentration on breath, yet letting it flow automatically, without controlling it. Success of my method is various, sometimes i can do 10 or 15 minutes no problem, but often when i do 20minutes i get restless, my mind wanders and it starts to become uncomfortable. Anyway my method is probably most similiar to thing commonly called as "mindfullness" method - pleb shit.
Recently i read few chapters of pic related (McMindfullness) where guy writes "mindfullness" trend is created by bloodthirsty capitalists to help wagies cope. I thought this guy has a point. For example today i listened to guided mindfullness meditation on DailyYoga app, and not only it was strikingly similiar to WakingUp one it also had mantra like "next time you will be in stressfull situation you will be calm and collected". Not only i felt dejavu (like i heard the same exact mantra before) but it sounds like clear cope for me - like stress is inevitable part of capitalism and your only choice is to "deal with it". I also use "yoga nidra" guided meditation videos to help me sleep. I thought its pretty helpful for that but i also felt this vague feeling of sadness toward end of this recording.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8mM5Oks8yZc
She says something like "imagine you are at the beautiful lake and you watch this big setting sun and you feel warm and calmness, and air is just like after the thunder, fresh and joyful" and i had this image of office drones in their 4 walls who never see things like that, and they need to be hushed and told bedtime stories like children or else they risk getting nervous breakdown. In summary - by my own thoughts and reading of pic related i realized mindfullness meditation is kinda mid fr.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
So i read /lit/ archive more. Some guy suggested "Keeping the Breath in Mind" as best "true" meditation manual. So i start to read it... I think in preface it had something about mantras and praying or something. And in first method guy says to inhale and say "BUU" than exhale and say "DHAAA" and some maybe usefull advice to find your breath comfortable so it will be easier to no longer control it. Thing is - i am not a buddhist, and i don't want to become one. I grew up in deeply religious family as a christian and even though i no longer attend church i dislike idea of converting to any other religion. Maybe i am even scared, if i get too deep into budhism i will get thrown into christian hell (years of indocrination must had some effect on me, and idea of sin is still real to me). Thing is i distrust christianity cause it's all about suffering and then eventual reward in heaven. There is no such thing as enlightment in christianity. They never teach you in church you will be happy alive if you stop caring about material things and dissapear inside yourself, its not about losing ego and being calm, but its about "carrying your cross" and shit. In that sense buddhism/hinduism seems more interesting to me, because there is some possibility of self-improvement, happiness here in the present. Not all about bowing before ever-present god who tries to make you kill your own son.
Anyway i heard about christian meditation and read bit about it, but it still feels fishy to me - you are supposed to concentrate on word of God? So you are supposed to memorize some Bible passage and "meditate" on it, just remind yourself of this quote over and over again? But then how is it meditation? Sounds like opposite of meditation to me, because you are constantly obsessing over thought (this single Bible quote or psalm), instead of "letting go" and just passive observing of physical processes of the body. How you can be passive observer if you have to constantly remind yourself of this "word of god"? But maybe its because of my misunderstanding of what meditation is and only knowing one variant of it.
So please guys can you recommend me some books about christian or secular meditation, that is not some cringe mindfulness marketing bullshit, but also not total buddhist bullshit? It may have elements of buddhist history in it, i don't mind. I just wonder if actual, based meditation can be done without buddhist mantras?

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
A philosophy professor standing in an auditorium filled with students asks one of them a question:
- Do you like soups?
- Yes, professor.
- So you know what soup is.
- Of course.
- Are soups good?
- Naturally, they are good.
- And is soup kisel? Can soup be milk?
- Yes.
- And you - do you think a soup is anything cooked as a stock?
- According to Wikipedia, yes.
A smile of superiority appeared on the professor's face
- Ah yes, Wikipedia!
And after a moment's thought he adds:
- I have an example for you. Let's say you have a stock of vegetables and meat. You add pants, stones and sawdust in there. Will it be a soup?
- Of course not, professor.
- So soup is something else than stock with additives!
- I think you can't put it that way.
- But why not? After all, this definition is on Wikipedia.
Faced with the student's silence, the professor goes on:
- It doesn't help, does it? My brother was a Wikipedia moderator and died of bitterness not being able to define soup.
The student is still silent, so the professor adds
- You can't give an answer, can you?
To give the student a moment to think, the professor reaches for a glass from his desk and takes a sip of borscht.
- Let's start at the beginning boy. Is milk a dish?
- Well, no... it isn't.
- And when you add cereal in there is it a dish?
Without a moment's hesitation, the student answers
- Yes.
- Then what does being a dish depend on?
The student twitches all the way:
- On the method of preparation....
- Well, that's right. So it is the addition of the cereal that makes it a dish. Now tell me more son - is there a fruit soup in the world?
- There is Mr. Professor ...
- That is, fruit soup is present in the Universe. And it is, after all, the addition of pasta that creates, by analogy with cereal, a soup, right?
- Right.
- So spaghetti with sauce is a soup? Since adding cereal to warm milk makes soup, so does adding pasta to soup! And since adding pasta to compote makes soup, according to the rules of logic, adding it to tomato sauce also makes soup.
The student is again unable to find an answer....
- And are there stews, puddings, kisiels? All these foods that appear in the world around us and resemble soups without being them?
The student answers in a trembling voice
- They do appear.
- And are they soups?
Silence has fallen in the room, so the professor repeats the question
- If not, why not?
In the absence of an answer, the professor halts his step and begins to look around the auditorium. All the students freeze.
- Tell me - the lecturer turns to the next person
- Do you believe in the only correct definition of soup, that is, by enumeration?
- No professor, I don't believe it.
The firm tone of the answer catches the professor's attention. The older man turns to the student:
- Ahh, then why don't you suggest something better?
- Soup has no definition honestly.
The professor smiles slightly while looking at the student. It promises to be a good semester.
- What do you mean to tell me young man?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21268858
- What I am getting at, Professor, is that the assumptions of your reasoning are false from the very beginning, so the conclusion drawn is also false.
This time there is a look of astonishment on the professor's face:
- False? How are you going to explain this to me?
- The assumptions of your considerations are based on an incorrect use of language, the student explains. You believe that there are definitions of all the phrases we use by giving necessary and sufficient conditions for being something. There are similarities between words like the similarities between family members. Family members do not have a single characteristic that distinguishes them. They are loosely related sets of characteristics, impossible to define.
The professor shakes his head still smiling, having realized the direction in which the student's argument is heading. A very good semester, indeed.
- To make you realize the way you manipulated my predecessor, let me give you another example - the student looks around the room.
- Can any of you define a game?
The audience bursts out laughing.
-Can any of you name one characteristic that all games have in common?
A dead silence falls in the room. The professor looks at the student with eyes wide with disbelief. After a moment of silence, which to everyone seems to last an eternity, the professor chokes out:
- It seems that we need to look at how we use language when talking about games..........
So, you admit that certain definitions do not exist, and what's more, words that cannot be defined are an essential part of our everyday life. Now, Professor, tell me, is there such a thing as a common characteristic of all soups?
Unsure of the answer, the professor says:
-Being an element of a set of theories of soups defined by enumeration....
-And what determines assignment to this set? An arbitrary decision by the professor? If to be a soup is to belong to a set of soups, and the condition for belonging to a set of soups is to belong to that set, then isn't this reasoning a bit circular?
The professor slumped inertly in his chair.
That student was the late Ludwig Wittgenstein.

>>21267443
>I am particularly interested in his comments regarding the value of Christian beliefs!

Read William James’ Varieties of Religious Experience and his essays on pragmatism. James was one of North America’s first psychologists, and one of the first to take religion and mysticism seriously. In contrast with Freud, who characterized religion as fundamentally “infantile”, James argued that “God is real because his effects on the human psyche are real” (paraphrasing). And the truth of an idea, according to James, is judged by how it influences human action. He lauds religions like Buddhism and Christianity in which “the pessimistic elements are the most developed”, as they presumably brace people to confront tragedy. He loves Tolstoy and Dostoevsky.

I think in this area JP owes more to James than to Jung, as his argument about the validity of Christianity is an inchoate version of James’. I’m not sure whether Peterson was actually directly influenced by James, or just came to similar conclusions by reading a bunch of boomer shit like Carl Jung and Joseph Campbell.

In general, I think in North America today there’s a popular pragmatic revival of which Jordan Peterson is a part. You observe the same sort of thinking among TRAD and orthodox LARPers, with people like Dasha Nekrasova purporting to believe in Christianity because it encourages people to exercise self-restraint.

All of this is, of course, heretical. IMO it’s a monstrous perversion of religion into something that is essentially therapeutic and nothing more.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21266123
Kant didn't even come up with it, he copied it from Leibnitz's Essays on Metaphysics where Leibnitz made the distinction between an essential truth whose truth is determined via the law of non-contradiction and a contingent truth whose truth is determined "ex hypothesi", ie dependent upon "God's will", which is contingent (unnecessary) circumstances, ie synthetically connecting things which don't have to be connected. It's valid as far as that goes, Kant's problem was dividing the judgements into a priori and a posteriori, which is something he also took from Leibnitz and modified into a slightly different form.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21266998
>which is something he also took from Leibnitz and modified into a slightly different form.
how?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21267672
Because Kant assumed that there was an intrinsic divide between the human mind and reality, whereas Leibnitz was correct in asserting that reality itself is contained within the monad which is an intelligent being, which is the only way any intelligent being can even make predictions about the phenomena it perceives (which we actually do). Leibnitz argues quite persuasively that the only difference between an a priori and posteriori truth is that a priori comes from having entire knowledge of a concept (given that human beings as such, and their entire universal destiny, are contained in their monadic concept, along with the substance they are typically accustomed to, namely physical reality, which is just one perspective of God's, there being indefinitely many perspectives and substances, all created through God's vision/glory). Therefore an a posteriori judgement is one formulated about a concept of which one only has incomplete information, not a judgement which is given specifically "empirically" as opposed to transcendentally, which Kant argued.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21268915
Here's a write up I did for for it:

The meaning of 'rir hallamut' (ריר חלמוֹת) is disputed, mainly because the meaning of 'hallamut' is unknown. 'Rir' usually means saliva but means sap or juice when referring to a plant, it can also be interpreted generically as a slime. So Job is asking "Does 'hallamut' slime have any flavour?", this is a rhetorical question meaning that it has no flavour, shown by the previous line "Can one eat tasteless foods without salt?"

Several scholars have identified 'hallamut' as a plant, but unfortunately Biblical commentators aren't botanists and use common names which could refer to several different species. A common identification is mallow, which usually refers to several edible species of the Malvaceae family which produce mucilage used in herbal medicines. Another plant candidate often cited is "purslane", the name of several edible plants, usually species of the Portulaca or Claytonia genera. Clines (1989) confusingly refers to it as leguminous, despite none of the common Purslanes being in the legume family (Fabaceae). UBS (1980) interprets it as yet another plant, the edible succulent Suaeda asphaltica, which they confusingly call purslane. UBS (1980) also notes that Hebrew peasants might not have distinguished between different plants and that the same Hebrew word could also refer to Atriplex halimus, the Tree Purslane, which the book oddly calls mallow.

The edible plant interpretation is supported by the later Aramaic usage of the word 'hallamut' to mean the "juice of mallow", and by the possibly related word 'sam hilimitu' (from the Amorite Alalakh tablets) referring to an unidentified substance associated with grains, so possibly an edible plant product.

Other scholars have identified it as the white of an egg, supported by the interpretation in the Aramaic Targum translation. Presumably raw egg white which is slimy and not very tasty. Yet another interpretation is that 'hallamut' is cognate with the Arabic 'halum' (halloumi) and would refer to the milky liquid exuded from raw soft cheese. A medieval rabbinic interpretation from the commentator Rashi is that it refers to saliva produced from eating strong-tasting foods such as garlic, he bases his view on etymological word play.

So what we know is that it was an edible liquid or slime without much taste, which Job uses to illustrate his lack of appetite for continuing either his suffering or argument with his friends.

Clines, David J.A. (1989) Job 1-20. Word Biblical Commentary. Dallas, TX: Word Books

Hartley, John E. (1988) The Book of Job. The New International Commentary on the Old Testament. Grand Rapids, MI: Eerdmans

Rosenberg A.J. (ed.) (n.d.) The Complete Jewish Bible with Rashi Commentary. Available at: https://www.chabad.org/library/bible_cdo/aid/63255/jewish/The-Bible-with-Rashi.htm

UBS (1980) Fauna and Flora of the Bible. 2nd edn. London: United Bible Societies, pp. 136-137, 170-171

threads.sub: /fic/ storytime : the ghast employer and how the revolution began
threads.com:
Jim found himself in his employers office, holding a list of grievances co-signed by the staff of his floor. What had brought him to this point? The ill-stewardship of his employer, yes, and the many foolish impositions put upon him and his colleagues; all none related to the work but imposed as it were merely to grind-down the will into submission. He had not expected, however, his employer to utter the words that came now,

"I will replace you all with black people," were what the employer simply said, with a look of disassociative serenity, "and perhaps women as well."

Jim was thrown off balance by this and he spun all around like a spinning-top and crashed into the wall. He cried out in terror and then he saw his employer, while having moved not at all, was now levitating with his desk and chair and nearing ever closer to Jim. The small mouth of his employer turned into a chasming maw and ghostly reverberations sounded from within the pit of his tummy, "but I cannot let you leave, knowing of my plans."

Suddenly the door to the office burst open and the employer gave a long guttural hiss.

"Arthur!" cried Jim, extending an arm to the only black colleague in the building.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
"Gosh!" exclaimed Arthur, "I feared all along that our employer was one of them," and he tore a shotgun from his back, "Jim," he said, a bead of sweat falling from his brow to his spectacles, "he means to replace us all with ghetto blacks, he was never an equal opportunist who did not see race - he hired me," he said, "thinking I was a pliant sort who would acquiesce! He meant to elevate me and when I said 'NO, I WILL NOT' he said I would regret it, but," and Arthur aimed the shotgun, "who will regret what, Mr. Cavendish?"

Jim snarled at the employer, "we've got you now," he chuckled.

Mr. Cavendish hovered mid-air, as if appraising the situation, "no," he said, "there is no means by which you will win here. You may kill me but another exactly like me will be sent from head office," and he smiled, "we are merely worker bees; wasps if you will, serving our hive queen. You Americans are nothing. We are sustained by psychokinetic energies, purest vitae from the screaming mouths of babes."

Jim gasped, Arthur gasped. It was a thing they had always secretly suspected but never given voice to before.

"it may be true, what you say, Mr. Cavendish," said Jim, "but you've forgotten one little thing."

"And what is that?!" roared Mr. Cavendish, his beige lips forming a disgusting visage, an expression of insatiable lust which then turned to terror at what Jim now held in his hand.

"just a little book by Thomas Jefferson," drawled Jim.

Mr. Cavendish inhaled deeply, "now just wait," but it was too late.

No sooner had Jim begun to read from the Founding Documents then Mr. Cavendish lost his spell and his desk and chair clattered to the soft carpeted flooring, leaving him all of a sudden impotent.

"My magics," he complained, as like a spoiled child whose ball had been taken from him by a school master, "this is cringe," he said.

"And now," shouted Arthur, using his agility to leap to the top of the desk in a single bound, "the consequence and remedy!" and he stuck the barrel of the shotgun into Mr. Cavendish's face, and Jims pleads of reason went unheard under verses of Heart of Oak until the crescendo was reached and Arthur blew Mr. Cavendish's apart like a wet sack.


Jim fell to his knees, "violence," he breathed, "now we have lost morally," and he hung his head.

"Not so," said Arthur, "for did not General LayFayette do likewise unto the rebels?"

Jim looked up, a glimmer in his eye, "he did," and then he bounded to his feet, "by jove," he cried, "HE DID."


The Men embraced as brothers-in-arms as in the distance the wail of foreign sirens drew nearer. The wasps of Cavendish were on their way; thinking they came to apprehend mere lambs they would not reckon on the discipline and efficiency by which Jim and Arthur would dispatch them beforehand. After all, there were only a few hundred lobsterbacks in the city. When they were done away with the black quarter would dine on lobster stew.


fin.
id. ix epulum iovis. nov.

The Return of Jim and Arthur, Book the First.
ACT 1. Dashing.

When the lobsterbacks entered the building they had not at all banked on the resistance by which they were met. Their training had been sub-par; many were unmanly sorts and were relying, broadly speaking, upon the powers of terror by which a kowing citizenry was jointly trained to respond to their presence and loud voices, to immediately follow instruction to surrender and whilst grinning like apes they would manhandle as thy saw fit until further instruction had been received.

However on this occasion no sooner had they barged through the revolving doors than their first company, oft' named in quainter times The Forlorn Hope, crashed through the flooring and onto a pit of sharpened metal and lead piping in the chambers beneath. Howls of agony and the sound of bone scraping against blunted piping rang in ghast symphonies up through what seemed then like the open pits of hell.

From the floorboards climbed soldiery, not citizens but soldiery. They bore down the collapsing column of lobsterbacks who, now met with hacking and stabbing, began to attempt a retreat out upon the open streets where their numbers would fare more in their favor. Had they received more than cursory training this maneuver may have spared them some losses, whereas in panic and disarray their attempts to withdraw and regroup offered nothing but to leave the backs of their legs and necks exposed to hammer and puncture, as sharpened piping maimed them from the knees down and other, cruder, weaponry inserted itself up and around the base of their skulls and the tips of their spines.

Many pleaded for their lives, forgetting their station and uniform, as common dogs.

More were grabbed as they tried to flee, others still were dragged by the broken legs and disjointed mangled arms and pulled back into the slaughterhouse.


Jim and Arthur were in the thick of it, not a single co-worker killed or maimed moreso than did these brothers-in-arms. By the end of the battle Arthur had begun to eat from the flesh of the riot officers; bare to the waist and his chest painted in spilled blood taken by fingertip of veteran colleagues and marked with the signs of emergent memories. Jim, for his part, stalked clad in snatched armor around and about the mouth of hell, delivering shattering blows to those either trying to escape from the pit or those half dead and dying impaled on the jutting beams.

Their efforts had been a complete victory. The entire enemy had been destroyed and their transports sat empty in streets emptier yet. More had joined as the fray had continued; thunder had sounded joined by the crackling of small arms as the enemy had rallied to its reinforcements and attempted one last desperate counter-surge before being torn to pieces.

Now all the bodies, stripped of armament, were hauled by the ton into the mouth of hell and still cries and wails came from down there as bodies crushed bodies and awakened those who had slumbered due to wounds. Just like that the New Army had gained armor superiority and even the firearms would prove yet useful; electronic shock guns that could incapacitate a quarry, large bore shotguns that would fare as company-breakers, door-breakers and mortars. Most of all value were the shields; these rectangular things that could repel bullets long enough to stave an eye-socket were of the greatest value of all.

But no mere Spartacus did either Jim, Arthur or the New Army fancy themselves; rather 'they' were Publius Licinius Crassus and 'they' were hunting down the rebel slaves, these lobsterbacks of Cavendish; these poor levies guiled to abuse the rights of Man with reckless abandon, knowing full and well the brunt of reclamation that they would suffer with their naked soft flesh in misguided attempts to insulate Cavendish for but moments until the New Army bore down upon him at each quarter and twisted foot from ankle, forearm from elbow and then tore asunder to peck clean the horish trunk.


T'was no rebellion, t'was but swift march.

"March on," sang the countrymen locked in their homes, "deliver us, deliver us, deliver us," they sang.


END OF ACT 1. Dashing.

2/2

>The ball was only just beginning as Kitty and her mother walked up the great staircase, flooded with light, and lined with flowers and footmen in powder and red coats. From the rooms came a constant, steady hum, as from a hive, and the rustle of movement; and while on the landing between trees they gave last touches to their hair and dresses before the mirror, they heard from the ballroom the careful, distinct notes of the fiddles of the orchestra beginning the first waltz. A little old man in civilian dress, arranging his gray curls before another mirror, and diffusing an odor of scent, stumbled against them on the stairs, and stood aside, evidently admiring Kitty, whom he did not know. A beardless youth, one of those society youths whom the old Prince Shtcherbatsky called “young bucks,” in an exceedingly open waistcoat, straightening his white tie as he went, bowed to them, and after running by, came back to ask Kitty for a quadrille. As the first quadrille had already been given to Vronsky, she had to promise this youth the second. An officer, buttoning his glove, stood aside in the doorway, and stroking his mustache, admired rosy Kitty.

>Although her dress, her coiffure, and all the preparations for the ball had cost Kitty great trouble and consideration, at this moment she walked into the ballroom in her elaborate tulle dress over a pink slip as easily and simply as though all the rosettes and lace, all the minute details of her attire, had not cost her or her family a moment’s attention, as though she had been born in that tulle and lace, with her hair done up high on her head, and a rose and two leaves on the top of it.

>When, just before entering the ballroom, the princess, her mother, tried to turn right side out of the ribbon of her sash, Kitty had drawn back a little. She felt that everything must be right of itself, and graceful, and nothing could need setting straight.

>It was one of Kitty’s best days. Her dress was not uncomfortable anywhere; her lace berthe did not droop anywhere; her rosettes were not crushed nor torn off; her pink slippers with high, hollowed-out heels did not pinch, but gladdened her feet; and the thick rolls of fair chignon kept up on her head as if they were her own hair. All the three buttons buttoned up without tearing on the long glove that covered her hand without concealing its lines. The black velvet of her locket nestled with special softness round her neck. That velvet was delicious; at home, looking at her neck in the looking-glass, Kitty had felt that that velvet was speaking. About all the rest there might be a doubt, but the velvet was delicious. Kitty smiled here too, at the ball, when she glanced at it in the glass. Her bare shoulders and arms gave Kitty a sense of chill marble, a feeling she particularly liked. Her eyes sparkled, and her rosy lips could not keep from smiling from the consciousness of her own attractiveness. She had scarcely entered the ballroom and reached the throng of ladies, all tulle, ribbons, lace, and flowers, waiting to be asked to dance—Kitty was never one of that throng—when she was asked for a waltz, and asked by the best partner, the first star in the hierarchy of the ballroom, a renowned director of dances, a married man, handsome and well-built, Yegorushka Korsunsky. He had only just left the Countess Bonina, with whom he had danced the first half of the waltz, and, scanning his kingdom—that is to say, a few couples who had started dancing—he caught sight of Kitty, entering, and flew up to her with that peculiar, easy amble which is confined to directors of balls. Without even asking her if she cared to dance, he put out his arm to encircle her slender waist. She looked round for someone to give her fan to, and their hostess, smiling to her, took it.

>“How nice you’ve come in good time,” he said to her, embracing her waist; “such a bad habit to be late.” Bending her left hand, she laid it on his shoulder, and her little feet in their pink slippers began swiftly, lightly, and rhythmically moving over the slippery floor in time to the music.

>“It’s a rest to waltz with you,” he said to her, as they fell into the first slow steps of the waltz. “It’s exquisite—such lightness, precision.” He said to her the same thing he said to almost all his partners whom he knew well.

The whole gown was trimmed with Venetian guipure. On her head, among her black hair—her own, with no false additions—was a little wreath of pansies, and a bouquet of the same in the black ribbon of her sash among white lace. He flushed slightly, and hurriedly asked her to waltz, but he had only just put his arm round her waist and taken the first step when the music suddenly stopped. threads.com:
I was thinking about what makes art art. And I think I came up with a very succinct, all-encompassing definition. Simpler definitions are better than very elaborate ones, who have to deal with a lot of exceptions.

Art is self-contained. A picture, a book, a musical piece are self-contained entities. There are no expansion packs for a book or a DLC for music. They are judged on their own. Context might help you to appreciate and understand them better, but the other work of an artist are all separate self-contained art pieces.

This is why games, tv shows, comics, etc are not art. Because they are not self-contained. This is why the upper class had such disdain for penny dreadfuls, who started the trend of not telling self-contained stories, but having the same protagonist, like a detective for example, always encountering new monsters, finding new lover interests, repeating the same themes over and over again. A game's lore and universe can always be ruined by a sequel, who in an effort to subvert expectations now tells you how the evil enemy you fought all along were actually dindu nuffins. Or how a culture, where all of the druids are male and the all of the priestess are female now has men in dresses and female furries.

Haven't seen Culture of Critique mentioned unless it's in one of those shitty infographs I never read. That's a travesty and a key to understanding a lot of what's going on in the world today. Definitely an eye-opener for the uninitiated.For a more balanced worldview I'd recommend Ship of Fools by Tucker Carlson, The Divide and Griftopia by Matt Taibbi, Death of the West by Pat Buchanan, and Camp of the Saints by Jean Raspail. All great in their own right.

For some entertainment purposes, Hunter and The Turner Diaries are fun if not particularly well-written, and Siege reads like a schizophrenic's diary. If you're looking for mindless brutality written by folks exposed as actual federal agents for the express purpose of radicalizing potential domestic terrorists, Iron Gates (I think that's what it's called) is kind of a WN version of an Edward Lee book replete with rape and torture. Adjustment Day by Palahniuk is an ambitious and entertaining read, but the execution of a great idea admittedly leaves something to be desired.

If you want something heavier, go with just about anything from David Irving. Hitler's War is probably his masterpiece, but his Goebbels's biography is great as well. Hitler's Table Talk is also a good read, although I've heard its veracity has been called into question on more than one occasion. Of course read Mein Kampf. Can't go wrong with Machiavelli either.

Saving the best for last, Jim Goad's Redneck Manifesto might be my all-time favorite book of any genre. You'll laugh, learn, be pissed off and you'll likely come back to it for another reading at least once a year. Outstanding writer and a 10/10 book. You won't be disappointed, particularly if you come from a middle class/lower middle class background and are sick of being blamed for all of society's ills despite a life of despair and constant recriminations despite yielding no institutional power whatsoever.

Hope you find something you like in there, anon. Happy reading.

I went to an all-boys boarding school (plus had a fairly distant relationship with my father and overly close one with my mother) which caused a lot of adolescent attraction to other boys. However, as soon as I got to uni and realised that girls actually existed (outside of internet pornography, which unfortunately had been my main exposure to them), I began to realise after about a year and a bit that I was lying to myself and was actually always attracted to girls. I sort of knew this, but I convinced myself that I was only capable of same-sex romantic attraction because that was all I had known previously, and it was also a convenient way of ignoring self-esteem issues which convinced me I wouldn’t be capable of getting attractive girls. It actually took a girl — who unfortunately I wasn’t interested in — taking me out on three dates until I realised that I could be attractive to some girls, and even then it took a couple of months to realise what I actually wanted and change my Tinder settings to women.
I don’t think I’m typical of most ‘formerly homosexual’ people at all, although the experience of people going to non-co-ed boarding schools and developing attractions to the same sex that they then grow out of is fairly common. I still feel attraction to feminine looking men, but I don’t think there’s anything wrong with that, I just don’t act on it, mainly because there are a higher number of attractive women and also because having a woman in one’s life is more of a sense of achievement and fulfilment. Check your digit ratios, whether you have gay voice, whether you have ever experienced attraction to women — if you have a high digit ratio and almost never experienced anything other than same-sex attraction then it might just be genetic and something you just have to accept about yourself, if you have low digit ratio and have experienced attraction to women before, it’s more likely to be a case of inhibiting psychological factors. There’s nothing wrong with homosexuality if it’s natural for you, but if it’s because you’re genuinely confused then it may prevent you from living the most fulfilling life you can.

threads.sub: /rhet/ people who have never suffered : muses
threads.com:
If a person or society is, all the time, insulated from ever 'really' suffering, how would that person or that society ever be able to recognize the worth of things which are good and simple?

A Man or Woman could not, perhaps, understand the great fun and joy in "all things" until, perhaps, they have been put in a prison for a very long time or in some other way been made to suffer horribly. It is not that "ending" that suffering brings joy to them but that they see the whole world with new eyes; cherishing then what they had despised or not even recognized before. It is a strange thing to consider the spoiled child of a suddenly rich person; they seek to prevent the child from ever needing to want or suffering, as consequence they raise a creature who is dehumanized and seeks only to consume, which itself seems merely a larval state - as the birth of the person has been prevented from coming about; they demand to feed on the pap regurgitated for them and they writhe around - both literally and allegorically in all things that they do.

Indeed, it is the action of the self which is required to cut loose from the cocoon; an action of first true consciousness.

last_replies.name: Anonymouṡ
last_replies.com:
>>21267756
I don't mean "artificial" in the sense of "the activity itself is utterly pointless". That will only cause resentment. I mean "artificial" in the sense of "there is an activity which needs doing which is arduous / taxing / risky, and everyone should have to do it for a bit, even people who are theoretically rich enough to avoid it (e.g. by paying someone else to do it for them)".

To take the National Service idea as the obvious example: Let's assume you need an army. Instead of just having a class (or underclass) of private soldiers to take your risks for you, ALL the young men have to do it for a bit. This is sort of what Heinlein was saying in Starship Troopers — "If you don't serve in the military and risk your life, you don't get to vote."

It's easy to see how this might get eroded. People would say "well, what if we have some genius mathematician or violinist or something. We don't want to risk HIM; so those people get special exemption". But once you introduce that, all the rich people will make sure their children get exemption. It would be hard to enforce.


It was easier to do this sort of thing in the past because there was so much more legitimate opportunity / need for hardship. There was a huge amount of heavy lifting to be done, and really NOT having to do it was the very artificial lifestyle. These days it's the other way around.
